channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SEC-3144] NullPointerException when no SecurityFilterChain matches in WebTestUtils
item.description:
In WebTestUtils, around line 118:

List<Filter> filters = (List<Filter>) ReflectionTestUtils.invokeMethod(
 
				springSecurityFilterChain, "getFilters", request);
 
		for (Filter filter : filters) {
 
			if (filterClass.isAssignableFrom(filter.getClass())) {
 
				return (T) filter;
 
			}
 
		}

throws NPE if "filters" is null (as in my case).
item.summary: NullPointerException when no SecurityFilterChain matches in WebTestUtils

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Note that the relevant method:

FilterChainProxy.getFilters() may return null. I Still don't know why it is null in my case, but I don't expect much help there until I can provide my example.

Thanks for the report!

It appears the Spring Security configuration you provided does not match on the request you provided. For example, in Java Configuration if your configuration looks like this the filters would be null for a URL starting with /nosecurity/. More specifically, it would be null unless the URL started with /security/:

@EnableWebSecurity
 
public class SecurityConfig extends WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter {
 
	protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
 
		http
 
			// all of HttpSecurity will only be applied if the URL starts with security
 
			// this includes HTTP Response headers, processing of username/password, CSRF, etc
 
			.antMatcher("/security/**")
 
			.authorizeRequests()
 
				// these request matchers are determining authorization
 
				// in this instance anyRequest will only be URLs that start with /security/ since
 
				// none of this configuration is used unless the URL starts with /security/
 
				.anyRequest().authenticated()
 
				.and()
 
			.formLogin().and()
 
			.httpBasic();
 
	}
 
 
 
	@Autowired
 
	public void configureGlobal(AuthenticationManagerBuilder auth) throws Exception {
 
		auth
 
			.inMemoryAuthentication()
 
				.withUser("user").password("password").roles("USER");
 
	}
 
}

Similarly in XML:

<http pattern="/security/**" >
 
	<intercept-url pattern="/**" access="authenticated" />
 
        ...
 
</http>

This type of configuration allows you to split of security within your own application to have totally different configurations.

Yes, the url I passed did not match the security filter configured (not starting with "/security"). However the behavior (NPE) is confusing since if I do not pass any security information ( .with(user(...)) ), then the same call is possible in the test because Spring does not even check for filters.

Thibault Kruse Quite understandable. Make no mistake this is a bug in Spring Security's test module and will be fixed. Thanks again for reporting it. I was just trying to describe what was happening.

A possible workaround would be to use something like:

@EnableWebSecurity
 
public class SecurityConfig extends WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter {
 
 
 
	@Override
 
	public void init(WebSecurity web) throws Exception {
 
		web
 
			.ignoring()
 
				// ignore any request that doesn't start with /security/
 
				.requestMatchers(new NegatedRequestMatcher(new AntPathRequestMatcher("/security/**")));
 
	}
 
 
 
	@Override
 
	protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
 
		http
 
			.authorizeRequests()
 
				.anyRequest().authenticated()
 
				.and()
 
			.requestCache()
 
				.requestCache(new NullRequestCache())
 
				.and()
 
			.httpBasic();
 
	}
 
...

Please note that I have been affected by this again in the most unusual manner. My tests were working fine locally and on our gitlab CI server, but when running in our Jenkins CI, I got a weird behavior. The last of my test methods would always fail with an error like this:

2015-11-17 15:05:41,428 INFO [org.springframework.mock.web.MockServletContext:443] - Initializing Spring FrameworkServlet ''
 
2015-11-17 15:05:41,428 INFO [org.springframework.test.web.servlet.TestDispatcherServlet:488] - FrameworkServlet '': initialization started
 
2015-11-17 15:05:41,430 INFO [org.springframework.test.web.servlet.TestDispatcherServlet:507] - FrameworkServlet '': initialization completed in 2 ms
 
2015-11-17 15:05:41,451 DEBUG [....PairingResources:226] - reserve activation code of an equipment for newuser2@new.com
 
Tests run: 5, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 6.429 sec <<< FAILURE! - in ....PairingResourcesTest
 
testPairingConfirmRegistrationOK(....PairingResourcesTest)  Time elapsed: 0.085 sec  <<< ERROR!
 
java.lang.NullPointerException
 
	at ....testPairingConfirmRegistrationOK(PairingResourcesTest.java:96)

This was the FULL error, no more stack frames reported. And this happens always in the last SpringMockMVC test run, regardless or whether I duplicate or remove the given failing method, this NullPointerException would merely reappear in another test method.

By wrapping that code line in try/catch, I got the full StackTrace:

java.lang.NullPointerException
 
	at org.springframework.security.test.web.support.WebTestUtils.findFilter(WebTestUtils.java:118)
 
	at org.springframework.security.test.web.support.WebTestUtils.getSecurityContextRepository(WebTestUtils.java:57)
 
	at org.springframework.security.test.web.servlet.request.SecurityMockMvcRequestPostProcessors$SecurityContextRequestPostProcessorSupport.save(SecurityMockMvcRequestPostProcessors.java:435)
 
	at org.springframework.security.test.web.servlet.request.SecurityMockMvcRequestPostProcessors$TestSecurityContextHolderPostProcessor.postProcessRequest(SecurityMockMvcRequestPostProcessors.java:520)
 
	at org.springframework.test.web.servlet.request.MockHttpServletRequestBuilder.postProcessRequest(MockHttpServletRequestBuilder.java:691)
 
	at org.springframework.test.web.servlet.MockMvc.perform(MockMvc.java:144)
 
	at ...Test.testLoginSuccess(LoginLogoutResourcesTest.java:49)
 
       ...

I have no idea why I did not get a full Stacktrace, nor what is going on there that the test fails on Jenkins but not on my local machine. I still need to debug this further, this is just to notify you that related to this I had more woes.

So, at least I can tell what seems to fix this for me. I switched from

	<security:http pattern="/security/**" auto-config="false" use-expressions="true" entry-point-ref="authenticationEntryPoint">
 
		<security:intercept-url pattern="/api/admin/**" access="isAuthenticated()" />
 
		<security:intercept-url pattern="/**" access="permitAll" />
 
    ...

to:

	<security:http pattern="/**" auto-config="false" use-expressions="true" entry-point-ref="authenticationEntryPoint">
 
		<security:intercept-url pattern="/api/admin/**" access="isAuthenticated()" />
 
		<security:intercept-url pattern="/**" access="permitAll" />
 
    ...

(what changed is the pattern in the outer html tag). The first one gave the same NPE. Might be a different bug, I'll let you decide. Note the first pattern is what we used in the live system, and it seemed to work (note sure if the inner permitAll has any effect there).
This issue has been migrated to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/3343
